documents.title: afternoon summary
text: david cameron 's claim to have saved taxpayers £ 1.2bn by turning around the lives of almost 117,000 of the country 's most troubled '' families has been dismissed as pure unadulterated fiction '' .
cameron included the claim , which ministers have made before , in his speech .
jonathan portes , head of the national institute of economic and social research ( niesr ) , dismisses it here .
iain duncan smith , the work and pensions secretary , has claimed that labour increased tax credits to buy votes '' when it was in office .
addressing labour 's stephen timms in the commons , duncan smith said : we 've had a lot of labour people going on about tax credits .

i looked up how tax credits were increased over the period they were in government , and quite interestingly it appears just before every election , the labour government increased tax credits dramatically the truth is his government has always used benefits as a way of trying to buy votes .
a conservative mp andrew percy has said that that benefits sanctions are driving people to food banks .
speaking in the commons , he said : an excellent , non political food bank in goole tells me benefit sanctions are driving people to use them .
i support the benefit sanction system , but one issue that does seem to be a problem is the consistency with which benefit sanctions are applied .
can we have a review of this and ensure the recipients of those sanctions understand the consequences properly ?
but priti patel , a welfare minister , said there was no robust evidence that directly links sanctions and food bank use '' .
cameron has been criticised for using his speech today to suggest tax credits will be cut .
frances o'grady , the tuc general secretary , said : today the government has smashed the myth that it is the party for blue-collar workers .
tax credits play a vital role in making sure the uk 's working families are better off in work .
cutting this crucial benefit will consign millions of hard-working families and their children to living on the poverty line .

and jeremy corbyn , the labour leadership contender , said : in the face of huge opposition to austerity policies on the streets this weekend , david cameron says his government remain committed to austerity and have no plan for prosperity or economic growth .
why do cameron and osborne refuse to get the huge body of evidence that introducing the living wage is the surest , most effective method of ending benefit pay outs to the in-work but still poor ?
billions would be saved by the public purse if the uk 's nearly five million low paid workers received a raise to the living wage of £ 9.15 an hour in london and £ 7.85 outside london .

cabinet office minister matthew hancock has welcomed the fact that his department is flying the lgbt pride flag , in an apparent rebuke to philip hammond , the foreign secretary , who has told the foreign office and its embassies not to fly the flag .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .
here 's faisal islam , sky 's political editor , on david cameron 's speech .

faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) essentially the pm seems to be saying that tax credits are a causal factor behind a low pay , high tax , high welfare equilibrium faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) larger structural factors behind low pay though include : technology ( automation ) , trade , migration , limited labour bargaining power , and nick robinson , the bbc 's political editor , has written a good blog on the speech .
he says child tax credits are in the firing line .
here 's an extract .
the likeliest target appears to be child tax credit , which is paid to those on low incomes who are both in and out of work .
newsnight 's allegra stratton got the first whiff of this a couple of weeks ago .

she reported that ministers were studying the work of the institute for fiscal studies which noted that £ 5bn a year could be saved by returning child tax credit to the level it was just over a decade ago .

the ifs estimates that this would hit 3.7 million low income families by £ 845 per child - producing an average loss of £ 1,400 per year - although some of these would be future rather than current recipients .

the government have the ifs 's backing for saying this would increase work incentives although critics at the resolution foundation have pointed out that it would be the 30 % of the poorest usually out of work families who would suffer most .
the devil will , as they say , be in the detail .
it 's worth remembering that it is sometimes the smallest , apparently least controversial cuts that cause the most political pain .
ministers are well aware that when it was first proposed the bedroom tax '' was regarded in whitehall as a tidying-up measure and not a symbol of the government 's wickedness .
julia unwin , chief executive of the joseph rowntree foundation , the social policy thinktank , has responded to david cameron 's speech by saying he should think twice before cutting tax credits .
here is an extract from her statement .
tax credits are a vital tool to prevent people 's incomes slipping so low that their health , education and prospects are damaged .

to deliver on the government 's ambition to reduce the welfare bill productivity needs to be improved , employers need to pay higher wages , more affordable housing needs to be built , and the markets need to make sure the poorest people are not disadvantaged .
addressing these causes will help reduce the need for people on low incomes to rely on tax credits to support their incomes .
cutting welfare in isolation , without addressing the causes of poverty in the uk , will mean many families on low incomes will face increased hardship and insecurity .

documents.title: a labour leadership round-up
text: here 's a labour leadership contest round-up .
tim bale at the staggers has published the results of a survey of more than 1,000 labour party members carried out in may asking them who the next leader should be .
it found that andy burnham was the favourite , but that many people did not have a view .
true , andy burnham was - yet again - the front-runner .
but he was only the choice of 18 per cent of members - not that far ahead of chuka umunna ( who had n't yet dropped out when we started surveying ) on 12 per cent .
next came yvette cooper on 8.5 per cent ( ahead of dan jarvis , who had n't yet ruled himself out when we began ) on 5 per cent .

liz kendall , almost certainly because she was far less well-known , even by labour party members , than most of the others , was named by just 2 per cent - the same figure , incidentally , as the much better-known prince across the pond , david miliband .
jeremy corbyn , by the way , was n't put forward by a single respondent .
still , the most striking thing was that nearly four out of ten grassroots members ( 37.5 per cent to be precise ) said they did n't yet know who they wanted to succeed ed miliband .

add that to the 34 per cent who named somebody outside of the four candidates who eventually made it onto the ballot , and it 's obvious that an awful of a lot of ordinary members ' votes are still very much up for grabs .
we did n't , though , just stop at asking the grassroots who they 'd like to see leading the party .
we also asked them - and indeed the members of other parties - to rank the qualities they most valued in a leader .
labour members , it turned out , were much less likely than tory members to rank strength and authority number one , and much more likely to put having strong beliefs first .
interestingly , less than 10 per cent of labour 's grassroots put the ability to unite the party top of their list .

indeed , being able to unite the nation , being in touch with ordinary people , being a good communicator and appealing to the average voter all came higher , each of them being ranked first by around 15 per cent of members .
liz kendall has said britain could leave the eu by accident because of david cameron 's failure of leadership .

speaking to labour meps in brussels she said : the prime minister does not want britain to leave the eu , but as long as he keeps retreating in the face of his backbenchers , the danger is that britain sleepwalks towards exit .
brexit by design would be bad enough .
brexit by default would be a catastrophic failure of leadership .
yvette cooper is catching up with andy burnham in the contest to be the bookmakers ' favourite to win the election .
here are the latest figures from ladbrokes .
ladbrokes politics ( @ ladpolitics ) labour leadership race - how the odds have changed .
this is from paddy power .
long-time odds-on favourite andy burnham is on the drift from 5/6 to 6/5 with yvette cooper overtaking liz kendall as second favourite having received a steady flow of cash over the last seven days .
yvette cooper has been cut from 3/1 to 7/4 whilst liz kendall has drifted from 5/2 to 10/3 .
jeremy corbyn remains the 14/1 outsider of the four for glory and is the most likely to finish the last .
and william hill said cooper had edged even closer to favouritism to be the next labour leader '' as it shortened her odds for the fifth time in a fortnight .
fraser nelson ( @ frasernelson ) yvette cooper set to overtake andy burnham as bookies ' favourite .

wm hill odds : 6/5 burnham ; 6/4 cooper ; 4/1 liz kendall ; 16/1 corbyn robert philpot says in an article for the spectator that the key to understanding andy burnham is to realise that he sees himself as an outsider .

it would be easy to paint burnham 's change of direction 'all politics is personal for andy , ' says a friend of his , recalling the rupture which occurred when burnham , who had been expected to back david miliband , decided to run for the leadership in 2010 .
friends and allies urged him not to .
not only was it david 's turn , they warned ; he would embarrass himself by standing .

the advice , no doubt well-intentioned and ultimately prescient , enraged him , compounding long-festering insecurities and sus just as burnham continued to feel an imposter at cambridge , so too , argues a friend , he always seemed to feel that he remained outside new labour 's charmed inner circle .
others who had trod the same path from working-class backgrounds , such as alan milburn , david blunkett , john reid , hazel blears and alan johnson , did not seem to share the sentiment .
an analysis by talkwalker , a social media analytics company , has found that jeremy corbyn is the most popular of all the candidates on social media .
a survey of more than 500,000 posts on places like twitter and facebook over the last month found that he was the only candidate with positive comments outweighing negative comments .
burnham achieved the most negative comments .

here are the figures : jeremy corbyn 30 % positive , 23 % negative liz kendall 23 % positive , 33 % negative yvette cooper 21 % positive , 33 % negative andy burnham : 14 % positive , 61 % negative , mary creagh 19 % positive , 24 % negative but remember , if twitter was representative , scotland would have voted for independence by a wide margin .
and this is from the email that talkwalker sent me late in the afternoon on election day .

almost four times as many people claim to have voted labour ( 2500 ) than conservative , ( 777 ) on twitter , according to analysis by talkwalker , one of europe 's biggest providers of social analytics , monitoring global on line conversations across all networks and media .
dave rowntree , the blur drummer and labour activists , has backed kendall for labour leader .
two more lines from dwp questions .
the conservative mp andrew percy said benefit sanctions were leading to more people using food banks .

graeme demianyk ( @ graemedemianyk ) tory mp andrew percy says benefits sanctions do fuel food bank use - just after minister priti patel spent five mins saying they do n't and iain duncan smith , the work and pensions secretary , criticised a labour mp for suggesting that people were committing suicide after facing benefit sanctions .
rob merrick ( @ rob merrick ) suggestion that people have committed suicide after being found fit-for work at assessments is a `` disgraceful allegation '' , ids says
labour is urging david cameron to come clean '' about his proposed welfare cuts .
this is from chris leslie , the shadow chancellor .
the prime minister still has n't come clean and said exactly what cuts he is proposing .
the government have a clear choice - will they tackle low pay or will they hit the low paid ?
david cameron has already spent £ 25bn more than he planned on welfare because of low wages and rising housing costs .
david cameron concealed his proposals from public view throughout the election campaign .
it is time for him to spell them out and let people judge whether or not they are fair .
the child poverty action group said david cameron 's speech earlier missed the point '' about child poverty .
this is from its chief executive , alison garnham .
no moral mission involves taking away tax credits for our poorest children .
no serious plan for the low paid begins with making them poorer by cutting their tax credits .
you ca n't have one nation if children 's lives , opportunities and life chances at every turn are shaped and limited by poverty .

the government 's child poverty approach is failing but the prime minister 's speech today simply missed the point and failed to set out what his government will do to prevent his legacy being the largest rise in child poverty in a generation .
we need to move from denial to decisive action .
that means instead of highlighting symptoms of poverty , such as debt , he needs to tackle the root causes .
it is no good pulling bodies out of the river , without going upstream to see who is throwing them in - especially , if turns out the culprit is government policy .

the right choices that would reduce poverty include protecting children 's benefits with the same triple lock protection pensions enjoy , fixing the deep cuts to tax credit help for the low paid , tackling cripplingly high rents , high childcare costs and expanding free school meals .

documents.title: iain duncan smith accuses labour of using tax credits to buy votes
text: in the commons stephen timms , the shadow welfare minister , asks iain duncan smith if working people on tax credits will be better off or worse off after the £ 12bn welfare cuts are announced .
duncan smith says people will wait for the announcement .
but he says labour have been going on a lot about tax credits .
he has been looking at the figures , he says .
under labour , the value of tax credits always went up just before an election .
he tells timms : his government has always used benefits as a way of trying to buy votes .
iain duncan smith accuses labour of using tax credits to buy votes .
iain duncan smith parliament
the national deaf children 's society has responded to david cameron 's speech by urging him not to make any changes to disability living allowance .
this is from its chief executive , susan daniels .

families with deaf children who rely on dla [ disability living allowance ] are not the 'benefit scroungers ' of popular folklore - they are families working hard to support their children , often in very challenging circumstances .

we know that deaf children can achieve as much as their hearing peers given the right support , but if that support is removed we risk going back to the dark ages when deaf children were condemned to a life of isolation , loneliness and underachievement .
i urge the government to recognise the needs of all disabled children and ensure that this vital benefit is maintained in its current form for the lifetime of this parliament .
in the commons it 's work and pensions questions .

but disabled people need to be treated with kindness .
labour 's kate green , a shadow welfare minister , says disabled people need justice rather than kindness .
will duncan smith promise not to cut these benefits ?

and he says rachel reeves , the shadow work and pensions secretary ( who is not here because she has just had a baby ) said labour would be tougher on benefits than the tories labour can not have it both ways , he says .

but labour would not cut in-work benefits helping people on low pay , she says .

documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: david cameron has refused to rule out cutting disability benefits affecting those who work .

in a speech in runcorn , in which he also signalled that the government intends to cut cut tax credits as part of an effort to move from a low wage , high tax , high welfare society to a higher wage , lower tax , lower welfare society '' , he only gave limited assurances on disability benefits .

he said in his speech : whatever the pressures , we will stand by my promises to protect the most vulnerable - including the most disabled who can not work because that 's the sign of the compassionate country i believe in .

but some disability benefits are paid to people who do work , and in the q & a , when asked if he would rule out cuts to disability benefits , cameron just said : we are actually spending more per year on disability benefits than in the past .
i think that is important , helping the most disabled people .

according to the institute for fiscal studies , taxing disability living allowance and the personal independence payment , which would count as a cut for those affected , would raise almost £ 1bn , downing street has said that cameron hopes that technical talks '' about britain 's eu renegotiation demands will start after this week 's eu summit and that they will probably take several months '' .
some peacekeeping missions are to be counted as defence spending for the first time , the bbc has revealed .
ministers have been urged by the royal college of nursing ( rcn ) to reverse cuts to healthcare leading to higher rates of child poverty across the uk .

as the press association reports , at the rcn 's annual congress in bournemouth , dorset , delegates voted 99.5 % in favour of a resolution that rcn congress calls on council to lobby all uk governments to invest in our young people and end child health inequalities . ''
professor rod thomson , director of public health in shropshire and deputy president of rcn , said the government needed to invest in child healthcare to ensure a healthy population .
he said : you [ the government ] do not understand the evidence base of children in poverty . ''
david cameron talking to students during a visit to ormiston bolingbroke academy in runcorn where he delivered his speech .

documents.title: cameron refuses to rule out further cuts to disability benefits
text: q : do you rule out changes to disability benefits ?
cameron says the government is spending more on these than in the past .
he does n't say he will rule out further cuts .
cameron does not rule out further cuts to disability benefits .
q : if you cut tax credits , wo n't that make it harder for working people who want to get on ?
cameron says he wants to move from a low pay , high tax , high welfare society to one where people earn more , but pay less in tax and welfare benefits are lower .
q : [ from a charity ] i was delighted you mentioned social impact bonds in your speech .
cameron explains what social impact bonds do ; investors put money into welfare services , and then the money saved as a result of those interventions goes back to the investors .
britain leads the world with these , he says .
but government interventions matter too , he says .
he says louise casey 's insight , with the troubled families programme , was that families were getting lots of state intervention , but that no one was knitting it all together .
what they do is like old-fashioned social work , he says .

documents.title: cameron 's q & a
text: cameron is now taking questions .
q : wo n't your policies result in foreign nurses not coming to this country ?
cameron says he does not accept this .
the migration advisory committee has not put nursing on the list of professions where there are skill shortages .
he says he wants british people to be trained to do these jobs .
cameron is winding up .
within our grasp is the opportunity for every child in britain to have the chance to go as far as their talents will take them.building a brighter future is what politics should be about .
it 's what i am about.and it 's what this government will work tirelessly to deliver over the next five years .

cameron says he wants to help those in work on low pay , and he lists various measures that will to this : increasing the value of the minimum wage , raising the tax threshold and providing more free childcare .
cameron turns to work and welfare .
he says he will take a one nation '' approach to welfare reform .

whatever the pressures , we will stand by my promises to protect the most vulnerable - including the most disabled who can not work because that 's the sign of the compassionate country i believe in .
we will always protect pensioners , because they have earned a secure retirement .
and we will always make sure that work pays - so people in work are rewarded .
in particular , that means two things .
one - helping those still unemployed back into work .
so we will double down on our reforms to remove perverse incentives in the system , further rolling out universal credit and lowering the benefit cap .
and we will do more to improve the employment outcomes for disabled people and for those from ethnic minority backgrounds .

this is a fundamental part of what i called in the election campaign my 2020 vision with 20 per cent more jobs , 20 per cent more university places and a 20 per cent increase in apprenticeship take-up for black and minority ethnic communities by the end of the decade .
cameron turns to education , and he says the education bill getting its second reading in the commons today will push up standards .

documents.title: cameron says troubled families programme will be extended to 400,000 more families
text: camerons says he wants to support families .
for me , families are the best welfare system there is - so i have never been shy about supporting them in the work they do .
and he announces that he plans to extend the troubled families programme to cover 400,000 more families by the end of this parliament .
our troubled families programme , under louise casey , has changed lives .
by radically changing the way we deliver services to the hardest-to-reach families in our country , we have tackled worklessness , addiction , truancy and anti-social behaviour .
and i can announce today that almost all of the 117,000 families which the programme started working with have now been turned around - in terms of either school attendance or getting a job or both .
this has saved as much as £ 1.2 billion in the process .
and in the next five years , we will work with 400,000 more .
this is a real government success , and i want to extend this thinking to areas where state institutions have all too often failed .
cameron says troubled families programme will be extended to 400,000 more families .
cameron says he is not being anti government .
shen i talk about dealing with state failure , i 'm not making an anti-government argument .
i 'm making an argument about ensuring that government works .
cameron cites adoption as an example of an area where the state is failing .

in the past , some people have found it easier to fly half-way round the world to adopt rather than wait for the case system at home to finish agonising about placing mixed race children with white families and vice versa .
we are sorting this out .
sweeping away the ridiculous rules that stop children being placed in a loving home .
more than doubling the capacity of voluntary adoption agencies to recruit adoptersand securing a quicker approvals process so that adopters can now be approved in just 6 months .
of course there is much further to go - we need to continue to tackle the obstacles that stand in the way of children being placed with a loving family .
cameron says he wants to become more intolerant of government failure .
so many of our country 's efforts to extend opportunity have been undermined by a tolerance of government failure .
the failure to look after children in care .
the tolerance of sink schools that have failed one generation after another .
an acceptance of long-term unemployment among hard-to-reach individuals .
we have to end the complacency that has sometimes infected our national life , that says some problems are too big , and we can put up with second best .
for me , when it comes to extending opportunity , the next five years will be about a complete intolerance of this government failure .
cameron reads out the passage suggesting tax credits will be cut .
see 9.04am .
cameron is now saying more about what he describes as the wrong '' approach to extending opportunity .
the wrong track though , is to ignore the causes , and simply treat the symptoms of the social and economic problems we face .
too often that is what happens .
just take the historic approach to tackling child poverty .
today , because of the way it is measured , we are in the absurd situation where if we increase the state pension , child poverty actually goes up .

so what we have seen in the past is that governments respond by thinking much of the answer is to redistribute money through the tax and benefit system giving families an extra pound here or there so they move from just below the poverty line to just above it .
i do n't underestimate for one second the difference that extra money can make .
but that is n't extending opportunity .
it 's papering over the cracks , using welfare to present the veneer of fairness .
cameron says increasing state pension leads to child poverty increasing because of way child poverty is measured .
cameron is now on the right track/wrong track passage .
see 9.04am .
cameron is now talking about the steps the government is taking to spread opportunity .
first , it is following its long term economic plan '' , he says .
there is nothing progressive about wracking up debts .
cameron says he said after the election that he would lead a one nation government .
he means that .
it will help people get on , whoever they are and whether or not they voted for him .
he wants to extend opportunity , and what he calls the good life '' , to all .
david cameron is speaking now .
he is at a school in runcorn .
it is john bishop 's old school .
but he wo n't be as funny as bishop , he says .

documents.title: no 10 lobby briefing - summary
text: here are the main points from the number 10 lobby briefing .

10 downing street neal/afp/getty images downing street said that david cameron hoped that technical talks '' about britain 's eu renegotiation demands would start after this week 's eu summit and that they would probably take several months '' .

the prime minister 's spokeswoman said : we would like to maintain the momentum on the discussions that we have had so far and therefore pave the way to move towards technical talks following the european council [ this week 's summit ] .
those talks , one would expect , would take several months .
that suggests it is possible cameron could be hoping for a deal to be sorted in time for a decision at the eu summit in december .
the spokeswoman said that cameron discussed this during his recent talks with angela merkel , the german chancellor , and that merkel agreed that technical talks '' would be a good idea .
the two leaders will have another meeting on wednesday , when cameron travels to berlin for a banquet being held to mark the queen 's state visit .
at their summit starting on thursday , eu leaders will discuss what form those technical talks '' should take .
the spokeswoman said that cameron has already spoken to 20 eu leaders about his renegotiation demands ahead of this week 's summit .

he has not yet spoken to leaders from austria , bulgaria , croatia , greece , lithuania , portugal and malta , but hopes to have bilateral talks with some these figures before the summit gets underway in brussels on thursday .
downing street confirmed that cameron was not asking for britain to have a veto over eu laws as part of his renegotiation .
as the telegraph reports today , business for britain says this should be one of his demands .

but , when asked about this , cameron 's spokeswoman said : if you were effectively seeking a red card for a single , national parliament , then you would effectively be seeking to restore the national veto .
i have not not seen that on the table .
cameron was interested in giving national parliaments more power over eu law , she said .
but he was looking at ideas that would involve national parliaments acting together to block eu laws , not proposals that would involve a single parliament exercising a veto , she said .
the spokeswoman played down suggests that cameron would propose britain becoming some kind of associate member of the eu .
according to a sunday times story yesterday , some tories have floated this idea .

the sunday times said : senior figures have told mps the prime minister 's renegotiation plans go much further than he has publicly admitted , in an attempt to stem growing tory concern that he is not demanding enough from brussels .
several no 10 officials want to rebadge '' britain 's role in the eu to something like associate membership '' , to demonstrate the uk will have a new relationship with brussels .

terms like market membership '' , trading membership '' and executive membership '' are all circulating in conservative ranks , designed to reflect britain 's primary interest in the single market and the country 's heritage as a trading nation .
cameron 's spokeswoman acknowledged that different countries have different levels of involvement with the eu ; for example , not all are members of the euro , or the schengen agreement .
but she dismissed the suggestion that britain could be anything less than a full member .
she explained : you are either a member or you are not a member of the eu .
the spokeswoman said cameron still thought eu treaty change was necessary as part of his renegotiation .
last week , after meeting cameron , the irish premier enda kenny said cameron had not yet pushed for treaty change .
today the spokeswoman said that cameron was clear that the changes he was seeking would require treaty change , but that were were differing views as to how you can achieve that '' .
the spokeswoman said it was nonsense '' to suggest that cameron was seeking to close down the bbc .
the spokeswoman dismissed claims that knife crime in london was going up because the police have been told to reduce their use of stop and search .
the most recent figures , to the end of december 2014 , show a reduction in recorded knife crime , she said .
and she said making stop and search intelligence-led was leading to more arrests .
i 'm just back from the number 10 lobby briefing .
most of the questions were about the eu renegotiation , and here is the key line .

downing street said that david cameron hoped that technical talks '' about britain 's eu renegotiation demands would start after this week 's eu summit and that they would probably take several months '' .
that suggests it is possible cameron could be hoping for a deal to be sorted in time for a decision at the eu summit in december .
i 'll post a full summary shortly .
here is my colleague john harris on cameron 's speech .
john harris ( @ johnharris1969 ) cameron wants `` higher wage , lower tax , lower welfare society '' .so is basic idea to lower the `` welfare '' & hope wage bit magically fixes itself ?
i 'm off to the number 10 lobby briefing .
i 'll post again after 11.30am .
you can read all today 's guardian politics stories here .
as for the rest of the papers , here is the politicshome list of top 10 must-reads , and here is the conservativehome round-up of today 's politics stories .
and here are four articles i found interesting .

emily dugan in the independent says that a royal college of nursing projection suggests stringent immigration rules will fuel a critical shortage of nurses in britain , cause chaos '' in hospitals and cost the nhs millions .

up to 3,365 nurses currently working in britain are likely to be affected by a policy which says migrants from outside europe must earn £ 35,000 or more if they are to be allowed to stay on after six years working here .
nurses rarely receive such salaries - particularly not within six years of starting work in the nhs .
the loss of these skilled clinicians will compromise patient safety , the nurses ' union says .
as nurses with rejected visas return to their home countries it would also mean the nhs had wasted more than £ 20m on the recruitment of staff who can no longer stay on .
the effects of the new rules will start to be felt in 2017 .

james kirkup in the daily telegraph says a report from business for britain says david cameron should lead britain out of the eu if he is unable to secure a veto for the uk over european laws , win back control over employment rules and permanently protect the city from eurozone regulations .

unless the prime minister can achieve a fundamental change in britain 's relationship with brussels , the country 's households and businesses will be better off if the uk opts to leave the eu , the report concludes .
the study , entitled change , or go , is the most detailed , fact based report produced to date on the uk 's membership of the eu , and the alternatives on offer .

it sets out ten major reforms that it suggests mr cameron must seek from eu leaders before the in-out referendum he has pledged to hold by the end of 2017 the report calls for the reintroduction of a national veto to be a priority in mr cameron 's renegotiation .
far more effective tools are needed to ensure that the uk could block measures that it fundamentally disagrees with , and these tools must be secured in any renegotiation , '' the study concludes .

examples of possible changes could be the securing of a genuine 'red card ' ( which would give legal weight to the parliaments ' opposition and would force the european commission to drop proposals ) or an entitlement for national parliaments to revoke eu law in certain circumstances .
these would , however , require treaty change to have legal weight and to be permanent . ''

fiona hamilton and richard ford in the times say a reduction in stop-and-search checks on teenagers , championed by theresa may , is contributing to a dramatic rise in stabbings , according to the country 's most senior police officer .
a reduction in stop-and-search checks on teenagers , championed by theresa may , is contributing to a dramatic rise in stabbings , the country 's most senior police officer has said .

sir bernard hogan-howe , the metropolitan police commissioner , is considering the increase of targeted stop and search in some areas after youth knife crime in the capital rose by almost a quarter in a year .
however , the home secretary made it clear last night that she expected stop and search to fall overall , and warned that she would introduce new laws if it did not .
boris johnson in the telegraph casts doubt on whether being a member of the eu is really worth it .
( johnson does not advocate leaving the eu , but his article does suggest he is becoming more withdrawalist . )
has it been much good for britain - or indeed anyone else ?
how has the sovereignty-prosperity trade-off really worked out ?
let us look first at britain , and the negative side of the ledger : the sacrifice of political independence .
it is considerable and yet i still think the british people would wear all this - all this loss of sovereignty '' - if the material gains were shown to be worthwhile .
but can they ?
how has this experiment really worked out ?
in the run-up to that 1992 single market , the eu published the cecchini report , prophesying untold riches for the continent .
by harmonising standards and blitzing national objections , the single market would unleash a frenzy of cross-border deal-making and dynamism .
to a certain extent , that did indeed happen .
but was it really attributable to brussels ?

and over the past 20 years , european growth has lagged way behind other regional economic groupings - asean , mercosur , nafta - none of which has these elaborate sovereignty-sharing arrangements , with a peculiar parliament and court and a vast and ever-growing corpus of supranational law .

indeed , you could surely argue that it is all this supranational regulation and legislation - so easily promulgated , so impossible to remove - that is now holding europe back ; one of the causes of endemic low growth and high unemployment virtually everywhere in the eurozone .

the whole tendency of politics today is towards localism and devolution ; and if we are going to give power to the nations and regions and cities of the uk , then surely it is time to give back powers to the countries of the eu .

the financial times story previewing david cameron 's speech ( subscription ) , which also focuses on his suggestion that tax credits will be cut , says there is little evidence that the generosity of tax credits leads to employers suppressing wages .
here 's an extract .
tax credits , at almost £ 30bn the biggest single area of expenditure , have made it feasible for millions to take on low-paid work but critics suggest they amount to a subsidy to business .

there is little hard evidence , however , that the availability and relative generosity of tax credits is acting as a form of corporate welfare , subsidising employers and enabling them to bear down on their own wage bills .
whitehall officials acknowledge that low pay is likely to become a key issue in the current parliament .

an inquiry into the issue by the resolution foundation , a think-tank that focuses on the plight of the squeezed middle '' , found wage growth had been no lower in the part of the earnings distribution where people receive tax credits .
nor did workers receiving tax credits appear to have seen lower wage rises than those not eligible for the benefit on the same pay .
according to the times , ministers are considering cutting tax credits so that they are only worth what they were in 2003 .
this is an extract from the paper 's preview story about david cameron 's speech ( paywall ) .
mr cameron 's decision to single out tax credits will be taken as the clearest signal so far that they will bear the brunt of the cuts to be unveiled in the budget on july 8 .
one option under consideration is to return tax credits to their 2003 value .
under the move , which would save around £ 5 billion , about 3.7 million low-income families would lose £ 1,400 a year .

although hugely controversial , some ministers believe a strong jobs market and tax change have created the conditions for a fundamental change that would shift the burden from the state to companies to address low pay .
in his speech mr cameron will say : we need to move from a low-wage , high-tax , high-welfare society to a higher-wage , lower-tax , lower-welfare society . ''
some tories hope george osborne will balance cuts to in-work benefits with moves to encourage companies to pay the living wage '' , an hourly rate currently set at £ 1.35 above the minimum wage .
senior government figures downplayed that , however , suggesting mr cameron was reluctant to introduce changes that could hit job creation .

in the light of david cameron 's suggesting that in-work benefits are too high ( see 9.04am ) , it is worth flagging up a newsnight report from last week claiming that , in government , there is growing interest in the idea that , to solve the problem '' of eu migrants claiming tax credits , one solution might be - to cut tax credits for britons too !
at one stage ed miliband ( remember him ? )
claimed the one nation '' mantle in british politics .

but on the night of his election victory david cameron grabbed it back ( rather audaciously , given the fact that he had just run a two-nation election campaign ) and today cameron will be giving a speech trying to flesh out what this means .
on saturday number 10 said this would be a speech on opportunity '' .
by last night , when downing street released a preview briefing note , the speech was being billed as one setting out his one nation '' mission to improve live chances for all '' .
cameron will say that there is a right approach , the conservative one , and a wrong approach , the labour one , to extending opportunity .
today i want to make a bigger , and deeper , argument about how we realise the one nation ideal and help everyone achieve their full potential .
when it comes to extending opportunity - there is a right track and a wrong track .
the right track is to recognise the causes of stalled social mobility and a lack of economic opportunity .
family breakdown .
debt .
addiction .
poor schools .
lack of skills .
unemployment .
people capable of work , written off to a lifetime on benefits .
recognise those causes , and the solutions follow .
strong families that give children the best start in life .
a great education system that helps everyone get on .
a welfare system that encourages work - well paid work .
these are the drivers of opportunity - and we need to extend them .
the wrong track though , is to ignore the causes , and simply treat the symptoms of the social and economic problems we face .
the speech get more interesting when cameron sets out an example of the wrong track '' , because he will argue that the growth of in-work benefits for the low paid has been a problem .
take for example the complacency in how we approach the crucial issue of low pay .
there is what i would call a merry-go-round .
people working on the minimum wage having that money taxed by the government and then the government giving them that money back - and more - in welfare .
again , it 's dealing with the symptoms of the problem - topping up low pay rather than extending the drivers of opportunity - helping to create well paid jobs in the first place .
so this is the change we need .
we need to move from a low wage , high tax , high welfare society to a higher wage , lower tax , lower welfare society .

yesterday george osborne , the chancellor , and iain duncan smith , the work and pensions secretary confirmed that they would press ahead with benefit cuts worth £ 12bn and cameron 's comments suggest a large chunk of this could come from tax credits .
